text: {"grade": 0, "reasoning": "The criterion requires the response to advise the client to claim trademark infringement under Section 10(2) of the Trade Marks Act 1994 (Likelihood of Confusion) as the primary cause of action. The candidate response lists UK Trademark Infringement as one of several applicable laws, stating: \"1. UK Trademark Infringement (Trade Marks Act 1994) - Identical/similar mark - Identical/similar goods/services - Likelihood of confusion - Reputation of your mark (if established)\". While it mentions the 'Likelihood of confusion' element, it does not explicitly state that the claim should be based *primarily* on Section 10(2) as the main cause of action, listing it alongside Passing Off, Copyright, and Design Rights without prioritizing the statutory infringement claim as required by the criterion.", "criterion_id": "2c1262d5-0b0b-4fee-a3bb-93d8a8541b92"}
